title: Ticket #7609: Submit.queue_with_itemdata() segfaults if iterator raises an exception
description:
Paul Skopnik reports on HTCondor-users:

The Submit.queue_with_itemdata method causes a segmentation fault when the iterator passed raises an exception during next(it). Submit.queue_with_itemdata() should check whether an exception occurred during next(it) and pass on this exception to its Python caller.

Minimal reproducible example: 

import htcondor

def my_it():
    raise Exception()
    yield {}

sub = htcondor.Submit()
schedd = htcondor.Schedd()

with schedd.transaction() as txn:
    result = sub.queue_with_itemdata(txn, itemdata=my_it())

I'd love if we could re-raise the exception that is raised inside the iterator instead of our generic RuntimeError.

Further update from Paul:

I discovered further details about the bug while attempting a workaround. I believe there are two separate but related issues.

## No 1: Segfault during queue_with_itemdata

The segmentation fault is caused not by the exception inside next(it) but by the Iterator yielding no elements ("length" of 0).

This code causes a segfault: 

import htcondor

sub = htcondor.Submit()
schedd = htcondor.Schedd()

with schedd.transaction() as txn:
    result = sub.queue_with_itemdata(txn, itemdata=iter([]))

## No 2: Late checking for exception

This is not a bug from a user perspective, but might be a programming issue.

The reason for the segfault in my original example is, that there is no immediate check whether an exception occurred during iteration. Hence, PyIter_Next returning NULL is interpreted as the iterator being exhausted.

The exception is then detected and raised to the caller later on. This can be seen in this code which sort of works as expected: 

import htcondor

def my_it():
    yield {'executable': '/bin/ls'}
    raise Exception()

sub = htcondor.Submit()
schedd = htcondor.Schedd()

with schedd.transaction() as txn:
    result = sub.queue_with_itemdata(txn, itemdata=my_it())
